speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Rob
text: And I’m Rob.

speaker: Neil
text: I’ve been reading about ways to protect the environment, Rob, and I’ve decided to eat less meat. And maybe drive my car less too.

speaker: Rob
text: Good for you, Neil! And flying less can also help reduce air pollution.

speaker: carbon footprint
text: Right. Flying and driving less are two good ways to combat climate change because they reduce your carbon footprint – that’s the amount of carbon dioxide or CO2 released into the atmosphere as a result of your everyday activities.

speaker: Rob
text: The idea of reducing carbon emissions is catching on in the music industry too. Bands and artists who go on tour around the world generate large carbon footprints.

speaker: Neil
text: So recently some music groups like Massive Attack and Green Day started thinking about ways to reduce the impact their tours are having on the environment.

speaker: Rob
text: Ha! Green Day – what a good name for a band trying to be environmentally friendly!

speaker: Neil
text: Today we’ll be finding out about bands and musicians who want to continue going on tour but do it in ways which reduce their environmental impact. And of course we’ll be learning some related vocabulary on the way.

speaker: Rob
text: So, it seems like the days of rock and roll stars flying around the world in private jets may soon be a thing of the past.

speaker: Neil
text: Indeed, Rob, and that brings me neatly to my quiz question. One British band recently announced they would stop going on tour until they were 100% carbon neutral, but which band? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: a)     The 1975

speaker: Neil
text: b)     The Rolling Stones, or

speaker: Neil
text: c)      Coldplay

speaker: Rob
text: Well, Coldplay had a hit with their song The Scientist, and we are talking about carbon dioxide and the climate, so I’ll  say c) Coldplay.

speaker: Neil
text: Good thinking, Rob! We’ll find out the answer later. But first let’s hear from another artist concerned about her carbon impact. Fay Milton is the drummer of the band Savages and co-founder of the climate pressure group Music Declares Emergency. She spoke to BBC Radio 4’s programme You & Yours:

speaker: turned downprecarious situationthe right thing to do
text: This year I have actually turned down a tour. My income comes from touring so it has put me in a bit of a precarious situation but I actually feel quite good about it – it feels like the right thing to do in this moment.

speaker: turn  down
text: Even though Fay earns a living as a drummer by going on tour, she has started to turn them down  – meaning to reject or refuse the offer of touring.

speaker: a precarious situation
text: Losing the income she usually gets from touring puts Fay in a precarious situation – a situation where things could become difficult, in this case financially difficult, because she isn’t making money from playing the drums.

speaker: do the right thing
text: But she still wants to do the right thing – in other words, do what is most fair, ethical and just. For Fay, fighting climate change is even more important than doing what she loves – going on tour with the band.

speaker: gigs
text: Well, good for her! I’m not sure if I’d be so committed as Fay. But if bands stopped touring altogether, fans wouldn’t get to see gigs – or live concerts and hear the music they love.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, that’s an interesting point because it might be possible for bands to carry on touring and also reduce their environmental impact at the same time. Bristol band, Massive Attack, want to do exactly that. Their singer Robert Del Naja explains:

speaker: the grid
text: We’re working with an electric bus company. We’re going to look at all the energy being renewable and obviously the power we can create will go back to the grid, so we’re hoping we can actually create legacy green infrastructure which can then power future gigs. We plan to travel to Europe solely by train, with the band, the crewand all the gear.

speaker: Rob
text: Swapping tour planes for trains and encouraging fans to travel to gigs by bus are two good ways to reduce the total carbon footprint of the concert.

speaker: the grid
text: And by using renewable energy, the gig can create power. This can then be put back into the national grid, called the grid for short – the network supplying electrical power across a country.

speaker: Rob
text: Well, Massive Attack are certainly ticking all the green boxes, Neil, but who else is doing a good job? Remember your quiz question earlier?

speaker: Neil
text: Ah, yes. I asked which band has decided to stop touring until their tours were carbon neutral and you said?

speaker: Rob
text: I said c) Coldplay.

speaker: Neil
text: And you were right! Are you a Coldplay fan, Rob? Just remember to leave your car at home the next time you go to their gig!

speaker: carbon footprint
text: Right! Today, we’ve been looking at some of the ways music bands and artists are trying to fight climate change. They want to reduce their carbon footprint – the amount of carbon they release into the air.

speaker: turn downgigs
text: Some musicians are starting to turn down – or refuse, long world tour dates because flying from country to country playing gigs – or live musical concerts, generates so much carbon dioxide.

speaker: do the right thingprecarious
text: Bands like Savages, Green Day and Massive Attack are trying to do the right thing -  taking the most fair and ethical course of action, even though for some artists, the income lost from not touring puts them in a precarious – or difficult situation.

speaker: he national grid
text: But when they get it right, bands can be carbon neutral or even generate power which can be put back into the national grid – the network supplying electrical power across a country.

speaker: Rob
text: All of which means we can ‘keep on rocking’ into the next century without increasing carbon emissions and adding to climate change.

speaker: Neil
text: So, Rob, you could say you were ‘born to run’… on renewable energy!

speaker: Rob
text: Ha-ha! Very funny, Neil. That’s all for today but remember to join us again soon for more topical discussions and vocabulary from 6 Minute English, here at BBC Learning English.

speaker: Neil
text: Thanks for listening and bye!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye.
